Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back originally well-modelled, now much abraded; prothorax division still visible, elytra line now rubbed off; at side, clearly defined legs; correct slope of back; underside deeply incised with representation of walking lion, with head looking forward and tail held high, sun-disc above back; distinctively shaped lion head and typical 'hockey-stick' legs as well as curved up tail; longitudinally pierced; pale blue paste of coarse texture; surface very worn.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs and scaraboids with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 34-45). This Egyptian Blue miniature scarab pertains to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Italy and Punic sites, and in Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 109-111, type XXX A, subtype A1-18, see especially A15 from Tanis as a parallel for this piece; similar motif found on pale yellow glazed composition scarabs: Gorton 1996, type XXVIII A6-39). For other Egyptian blue scarabs from Naukratis with a similar motif: Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H3804; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.685 and 88.866; Sydney, The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney NM00.128.5. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming.
